text: Apple announces a new standalone "Siri app" based on a new LLM that will...
full-pick-text: Apple announces a new standalone "Siri app" based on a new LLM that will be multilingual and support multiple languages at the same time, support multiple modalities – e.g. text input, voice input, and image attachments in the same conversation, and display content from third-party apps inline based on a new developer framework.
notes:
• "Be multilingual and support multiple languages at the same time."
  • "Support multiple modalities – e.g. text input, voice input, or image attachments in the same conversation."
  • "Display content from third-party apps inline based on a new developer framework."
  • If the overall pick about a "Siri app" is wrong, all the details will be counted as wrong as well. But that won't be a problem because Federico thinks that this approach is "so obvious".

text: Apple Music will be redesigned again
full-pick-text: Apple Music will be redesigned again
notes:
• "Will gain more Spotify-like algorithmic features"
  • "An Apple version of the Daily Mix and a way to discover back catalog songs from artists you don't know (Discover Weekly?)"
  • The New Music Daily feature would eventually come in 2019.

text: Apple opens up AFM (Apple Foundation Model) to developers
full-pick-text: Apple opens up AFM (Apple Foundation Model) to developers. It's a 3B parameter version only that runs on device. It's designed in a way that only specific "endpoints" can be used with a native API, like summarization or writing or prioritizing content. Apple shows off examples of how they're using the same tech in its own system apps.
notes:
• "It's a 3B parameter version only that runs on device."
  • "It's designed in a way that only specific "endpoints" can be used with a native API, like summarization or writing or prioritizing content." (In other words, developers won't be able to prompt the API with arbitrary text, they only have access to particular tasks like summarization.)
  • "Apple shows off examples of how they're using the same tech in its own system apps."
